author: djrtwo
content: You definitely will need to validate the block eventually. The question is whether you need to take the hit on timing to validate it before broadcast

author: djrtwo
content: If i had a VC connected to two BNs and I got a block to sign from one of them and wanted to broadcast via both, I'd prefer no validation on the BN that didnt originally produce the block for fast network dissemination

author: djrtwo
content: But the BN is taking on peer score risk depending on the behaviour of the validator

author: mpetrunic
content:
> If i had a VC connected to two BNs and I got a block to sign from one of them and wanted to broadcast via both, I'd prefer no validation on the BN that didnt originally produce the block for fast network dissemination
<@!291925846556540928> are you suggesting flag for validator to signal BN if block should be validated?

author: djrtwo
content: that wouldn't help! the problem is the BN trsuting the VC so a flag from the validator can't be trusted if you can't trust hte VC

author: djrtwo
content: I'm inclined to have a strong trust relationship assumed in the base API

author: djrtwo
content: and if instead you were a service provider, to have strong authenication and to add things like "only broadcast blocks, the BN previously handed out to be signed"

author: jgm
content:
> I'm inclined to have a strong trust relationship assumed in the base API
<@!291925846556540928> I'd rather the BN didn't assume trust, in that it verified all data coming in to it from both P2P and API.  It's a more solid basis on which to build, IMO.

If the API is considered "trusted" but the P2P connections aren't, it doesn't seem to be a major benefit to the network as a whole for the block received via API to not be validated, but for the block received via P2P to have to be.  Seems like we're not gaining a lot in terms of speed of transmissions (no verification prior to first hop) and, as you say, opening up the beacon node to being dinged on its score.
